thread.title: 5 famous figures in the history of LSD
thread.title_full: 5 famous figures in the history of LSD - NY Daily News

author: NEW YORK DAILY NEWS
title: 5 famous figures in the history of LSD
text:
Eve Mortensen/AP Timothy Leary is known as the LSD guru. He would be 95 Thursday. It’s time to turn on, tune in and drop out — Thursday would be Timothy Leary’s 95th birthday.
Leary is popularly known as the father of LSD, but there are actually a lot of other people who played key roles in expanding the popularity of the mind-expanding drug.
Albert Hoffmann
Hoffman, a Swiss chemist working in a research lab, was the first person to create lysergic acid diethylamide-25, the compound more commonly known as acid.
Though he invented the drug in 1938, it wasn’t until 1943 that he discovered its psychoactive properties — by accident.
PATRICK STRAUB/ASSOCIATED PRESS Albert Hofmann was the Swiss chemist who first discovered acid. Hoffman unintentionally consumed some of his compound and quickly noticed its effect. A few days later, he took it again just to confirm before later going on to report his findings.
Ken Kesey
After the success of 1962’s “One Flew Over the Cuckoo’s Nest,” 29-year-old writer Ken Kesey decided to go on a cross-country bus trip in 1963.
He went with his crew — called the Merry Pranksters — and they ingested copious amounts of acid along the way.
JEFF BARNARD/AP Along with his Merry Pranksters, author Ken Kesey spread acid across the country. Tom Wolfe chronicled their experience in “The Electric Kool-Aid Acid Test,” a book that did much to publicize the art of tripping face.
Oscar Janiger
Oscar Janiger was a Los Angeles psychiatrist in the 1950s who was interested in using LSD to treat his patients. So, he just politely wrote a letter to Sandoz, the drug’s maker, and was sent his own supply in exchange for an agreement to document patients’ experiences.
According to Vanity Fair , Janiger’s acid experiments quickly took over his practice as he became increasingly popular with Hollywood creatives.
ASSOCIATED PRESS Film star Cary Grant was a big fan of tripping face. Janiger certainly wasn’t the only doctor pushing psychedelic experimentation as treatment in the 1950s, but he was one of the best known.
Cary Grant
The old-time actor was a big-time proponent of tripping. He started taking LSD on the advice of his psychiatrist.
Although a lot of Hollywood types took hallucinogens for therapy, the “North by Northwest” star was notably public about his psychedelic adventures.
Ed Perlstein/Redferns Owsley Stanley was a famous acid maker in California. In 1959, he graced the cover of Look magazine for a profile of his LSD use, giving the drug positive press mentions and generated added interest.
Owsley Stanley
Rolling Stone dubbed Owsley “The King of LSD.”
He became known as a folk hero for the exceptionally pure acid he made and distributed in the streets of Haight-Ashbury in the 1960s.
In fact, he became so well-known for his trippy treasures that the Oxford English Dictionary actually lists “Owsley” as a type of acid.
